docs.snippet: Retail sales, in real terms, will rise 2 to 3 percent this year over 1982, speakers predicted yesterday at the opening session of a national retailing meeting here. But they estimated that sales in the 1982 retailing year, which concludes at the e...
docs.lead_paragraph: Retail sales, in real terms, will rise 2 to 3 percent this year over 1982, speakers predicted yesterday at the opening session of a national retailing meeting here. But they estimated that sales in the 1982 retailing year, which concludes at the end of January, would fall 1 percent from the previous year. Addressing about 1,500 participants at a morning meeting of the annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association at the New York Hilton Hotel, Robert A. Mooney, manager of corporate economics for the J.C. Penney Company, declared: ''After a 1 1/2 percent gain in 1982, general merchandise retail sales will be up 6 1/4 percent in 1983. Price inflation will account for just over 3 percent of these gains, leaving 3 percent real growth.''

headline.main: RETAILERS, AT MEETING, PREDICT 2-3% SALES GAIN

docs.snippet: Through eight years of bombings and other violent actions, a small Puerto Rican armed force known as the F.A.L.N. has established itself as one of the most elusive and resilient terrorist groups ever to operate in the United States, according to F...
docs.lead_paragraph: Through eight years of bombings and other violent actions, a small Puerto Rican armed force known as the F.A.L.N. has established itself as one of the most elusive and resilient terrorist groups ever to operate in the United States, according to Federal and local law enforcement officials. The officials, who include Lee F. Laster, assistant director in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York City, say that the F.A.L.N. -Fuerzas Armadas de Liberacion Nacional, or Armed Forces of National Liberation - remains a threat out of proportion to its size and lack of support in Puerto Rico and among Puerto Ricans on the mainland. A mark of its resilience, officials say, is its obvious resurgence less than three years after the arrest and subsequent conviction of 11 men and women charged with plotting and carrying out dozens of bombings and other crimes for the F.A.L.N. in Chicago and New York in the 1970's. The 11 were arrested on April 4, 1980, in Evanston, Ill., during what one later called preparation for an armored-car robbery. Last March, the F.A.L.N. first signaled its return to activity with bombings of four bank and securities buildings around Wall Street.

docs.snippet: EVERY evening for the last few weeks, about 50 men and five women have lined up outside a construction trailer on Mulberry Street in Newark and waited for the doors to open.   The men and women - young and old, white and black - come from a variet...
docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY evening for the last few weeks, about 50 men and five women have lined up outside a construction trailer on Mulberry Street in Newark and waited for the doors to open. The men and women - young and old, white and black - come from a variety of backgrounds. What they have in common, for the most part, is that they are derelicts who need a place to spend the night, a place away from back alleys and abandoned buildings. As temperatures drop, they leave their usual haunts and look for a warm spot to spend the night. The 12-by-60-foot trailer, which was opened just a month ago, provides a spartan, overnight shelter for the homeless. Metal folding chairs, a cup of coffee and the use of a bathroom are the only amenities offered by the Committee on the Homeless, a consortium of religious and social-welfare agencies.

docs.snippet: THE rush to get the new concert year under way has begun, and many of the county's top cultural organizations are readying their 1983 openers for this week or next. Today at 3 o'clock, for instance, the 17th season of Sunday concerts at the Hudson...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE rush to get the new concert year under way has begun, and many of the county's top cultural organizations are readying their 1983 openers for this week or next. Today at 3 o'clock, for instance, the 17th season of Sunday concerts at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers continues with a performance of Schubert's magnificent song cycle ''Die Schone Mullerin.'' The tenor is Larry Bauer and Mary Sadovnikoff, a champion of authentic instrument usage, will be accompanying him on a fortepiano such as Schubert himself most likely knew. Christ Church in Tarrytown is the meeting place of another fine chamber series, aptly titled Music for a Sunday Afternoon, and at 4 o'clock today, the violinist Robin Mayforth, the violist Keith Conant and the pianist Lisa Papili will join to play music of Mozart, Corelli, Handel, Sarasate and Wieniawski. ''I am particularly excited about this concert,'' said Dorothy Beach, founder and director of the series, ''because I feel that bringing such promising young musicians before the public is perhaps the most valuable function we can fill as a presenting organization.''

docs.snippet: PHILIPPE NOIRET, the distinguished French actor, can be sardonic in two languages. Talking about his current movie, ''Coup de Torchon,'' now playing at the Paris Theater, he says, ''Last year in France, we have 12 nominations for Cesar, which is o...
docs.lead_paragraph: PHILIPPE NOIRET, the distinguished French actor, can be sardonic in two languages. Talking about his current movie, ''Coup de Torchon,'' now playing at the Paris Theater, he says, ''Last year in France, we have 12 nominations for Cesar, which is our Oscar. And we avoid every prize.'' Even so,''Coup de Torchon'' has been chosen as the official French entry in the best-foreign-film category for the coming Academy Awards. Whether it wins or loses, Mr. Noiret will probably maintain his calm. He is not a flappable sort. The writer-director Bernard Tavernier, who made ''Coup de Torchon'' (and four other pictures with Mr. Noiret, including the well-regarded ''Clockmaker'') says one of the reasons he likes the actor is that he doesn't ask questions.

docs.snippet: On Saturday, Dec. 29, 1934, the first college basketball doubleheader was played at Madison Square Garden. Frank McGuire, then a St. John's sophomore, recently recalled that night when Westminster beat St. John's and New York University beat Notre...
docs.lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Dec. 29, 1934, the first college basketball doubleheader was played at Madison Square Garden. Frank McGuire, then a St. John's sophomore, recently recalled that night when Westminster beat St. John's and New York University beat Notre Dame.

byline.original: By Neil Amdur and Michael Katz

docs.snippet: President Fernando Belaunde Terry swore in nine Cabinet members today, including military men in all defense-related posts, in the most sweeping Government reorganization since he came to power in 1980.   Fernando Schwalb, former Ambassador to the...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Fernando Belaunde Terry swore in nine Cabinet members today, including military men in all defense-related posts, in the most sweeping Government reorganization since he came to power in 1980. Fernando Schwalb, former Ambassador to the United States, replaced Manuel Ulloa as Prime Minister and was also named Foreign Minister.

headline.main: Peru's Leader Swears In 9 Cabinet Members

docs.snippet: GEORGE RAINE contributes to The New York Times from Salt Lake City.   T he five Utah ski resort towns that hug the craggy Wasatch Range, each about 30 miles east or southeast of Salt Lake City, have distinct personalities, very much by the design ...
docs.lead_paragraph: GEORGE RAINE contributes to The New York Times from Salt Lake City. T he five Utah ski resort towns that hug the craggy Wasatch Range, each about 30 miles east or southeast of Salt Lake City, have distinct personalities, very much by the design of their developers. Now that they are joined - at least for the capable and hearty skiers willing to traverse the range's spine to participate in the Interconnect Adventure -visitors have the opportunity of sampling these diverse resorts in a single day. It would be difficult, however, to spend but a day in the stately mountains that rim the city.

headline.kicker: SELECTED REST STOPS ALONG THE TRAIL
